unit_type: Divisione di Fanteria Binaria (Binary Infantry Division)

commander.name: Pietro Maggiani
commander.notes: Promoted to Major-General on May 31, 1940 (with seniority from January 1, 1940). Commanded Savona from September 1, 1939 through November 3, 1941. Led division through Operation Compass period.

command.headquarters_location: Libya (exact location uncertain - likely Tripolitania region in reserve/garrison role during Q4 1940)

supply_logistics.supply_status: Adequate for defensive operations in Q4 1940. Division in reserve/garrison role during early Operation Compass period (December 1940). Supply lines from Tripoli via coastal road to forward positions. Fuel and ammunition adequate for non-motorized division. Water critical constraint for desert operations.

weather_environment.season_quarter: 1940-Q4 (October-December): Autumn transitioning to winter, cooler temperatures, increased rainfall
weather_environment.terrain_type: Libyan coastal and interior desert - rocky terrain, wadis, escarpments

operational_status.recent_operations: Division stationed in Libya throughout Q4 1940. Exact location uncertain but likely in reserve/garrison role in Tripolitania region. British Operation Compass began December 9, 1940 targeting Italian forces in Egypt. Division's artillery regiment (12° SILA) would be lost during British winter offensive 1940-41.
operational_status.current_mission: Reserve/garrison operations in Libya. Mission: maintain readiness, defend Italian colonial territory, support 10th Army operations if required. Division not deployed to forward positions in Egypt during initial Operation Compass period.
operational_status.notes: Combat readiness good (75%) for metropolitan binary infantry division. Morale good but untested in major combat operations as of Q4 1940. Division would face British offensive pressure in coming months, losing artillery regiment during Operation Compass winter 1940-41. Non-motorized status (horse-drawn transport) limited mobility compared to AS-type autotrasportabile divisions.

doctrine_and_tactics.primary_doctrine: Italian binary division doctrine - defensive operations with limited offensive capability. Non-motorized division dependent on horse-drawn transport.
doctrine_and_tactics.tactical_employment: Reserve/garrison operations in Tripolitania region of Libya during Q4 1940. Division positioned to reinforce 10th Army if required. Static defense of assigned sector. Limited mobility due to non-motorized status. Dependent on horse-drawn transport for artillery and supplies.
doctrine_and_tactics.special_capabilities: Standard Italian binary infantry division. No special capabilities beyond basic infantry operations. Division experienced in garrison duties but limited combat experience as of Q4 1940.
doctrine_and_tactics.limitations: Non-motorized division with very limited mobility. Dependent entirely on horse-drawn transport except for small number of command vehicles and limited truck transport. Operational radius only 50km from supply dumps due to horse-drawn logistics. Limited anti-tank capability (only 8x 47mm guns) inadequate against British Matilda II tanks (78mm frontal armor). Weak AA defense (8x 20mm guns) insufficient against British air superiority. Supply lines vulnerable to British interdiction.
doctrine_and_tactics.notes: Metropolitan binary division recruited from southern Italy (Campania and Calabria regions). 15th Regiment from Salerno, 16th Regiment from Cosenza. Non-motorized status distinguished Savona from AS-type autotrasportabile divisions (Bologna, Brescia, Pavia, Catanzaro). Division facing challenges adapting to North African desert conditions. Equipment and organization suited for European warfare, not optimal for desert mobile warfare. Division would lose artillery regiment during Operation Compass and ultimately be destroyed at Bardia November 1941.

subordinate_units.structure: 2 battalions (I and II), regimental weapons company
subordinate_units.notes: Binary regiment structure. Each battalion: 4 rifle companies + 1 machine gun company + 1 mortar platoon. Regimental weapons company included 81mm mortars and 65mm infantry guns. Home station: Salerno (Campania region, southern Italy). Regiment part of division destroyed November 1941 per US G2 records.

subordinate_units.structure: 2 battalions (I and II), regimental weapons company
subordinate_units.notes: Binary regiment structure. Each battalion: 4 rifle companies + 1 machine gun company + 1 mortar platoon. Regimental weapons company included 81mm mortars and 65mm infantry guns. Home station: Cosenza (Calabria region, southern Italy). Regiment part of division destroyed November 1941 per US G2 records.

subordinate_units.structure: 3 groups: I Gruppo (12x 75/27 - horse-drawn), II Gruppo (12x 75/27 - horse-drawn), III Gruppo (12x 100/17 - horse-drawn)
subordinate_units.notes: Standard Italian divisional artillery regiment. All groups horse-drawn - no motorization. Home station: Nola (Campania region). Regiment LOST during British Operation Compass winter 1940-41 per US G2 Order of Battle document. This represents full-strength organization as of Q4 1940 before losses.
Divisional anti-tank company. 47mm guns effective against light armor only, inadequate against British Matilda II heavy infantry tanks (78mm frontal armor). Horse-drawn guns limited mobility.

subordinate_units.equipment: Mine detectors, demolition equipment, field fortification tools, minefield markers
subordinate_units.notes: Division-level engineers. Responsible for field fortifications, mine warfare, and mobility support. Critical for preparing defensive positions in desert terrain.

subordinate_units.structure: Radio platoon, wire platoon, messenger platoon
subordinate_units.notes: Division signals. Limited radio equipment - relied heavily on wire communications. Wire networks vulnerable to mobile warfare. Communications with higher headquarters and subordinate units challenging in mobile desert operations.

subordinate_units.structure: MVSN (Fascist Militia) battalion attached per standard practice
subordinate_units.notes: MVSN (Fascist Militia) battalion attached to division. Provided additional infantry but lower combat effectiveness than regular infantry. Employed in secondary sectors and rear area security.

subordinate_units.structure: Main dressing station, ambulance platoon, 2 field hospitals
subordinate_units.notes: Division medical services. Limited evacuation capability due to lack of motorization. Serious casualties required evacuation to rear area hospitals via limited transport. Desert conditions created additional medical challenges (heat exhaustion, dysentery, water-borne diseases).

subordinate_units.equipment: Supply trucks, field kitchens, bakery equipment
subordinate_units.structure: Supply depot, bakery section, transport platoon
subordinate_units.notes: Division supply and logistics. Limited truck transport capacity constrained supply operations. Dependent on higher echelon transport for bulk supplies from ports. Water supply critical challenge in desert conditions.
Military police. Traffic control, prisoner handling, rear area security, enforcement of military discipline.
Ceremonial and morale purposes. Performed for troop morale during garrison duty in Libya.

subordinate_units.equipment: Additional Breda M37 heavy machine guns
subordinate_units.structure: 3 companies, each with multiple machine gun platoons
subordinate_units.notes: Machine gun battalion attached to division for additional firepower. Provided concentrated automatic weapons support for defensive operations. Typical attachment for binary divisions in North Africa.

sources.title: Order of Battle of the Italian Army, July 1943
sources.author: US Army Military Intelligence Service, HQ G-2
sources.details: 55th SAVONA Division (Infantry). Commander: [not specified for 1940 period]. Home station: Salerno. History: Located in Libya on 10 June 1940, when Italy entered the war. Lost its artillery regiment (12° SILA) during British advance in winter of 1940-41. Destroyed in November 1941. Composition: 15th SAVONA Inf Regt (home station Salerno), 16th SAVONA Inf Regt (home station Cosenza), 12th SILA Arty Regt (home station Nola), 55th Engr Bn.

sources.title: Technical Manual TME 30-420: Handbook on the Italian Military Forces
sources.author: US War Department, Military Intelligence Service
sources.details: Italian binary infantry division organization: 2 infantry regiments, artillery regiment (36 guns: 24x 75mm, 12x 100mm), AT company (8x 47mm guns), AA battery (8x 20mm guns), engineer company, signals company. Personnel: ~10,500-11,000 for standard binary division. Each infantry regiment: 2 battalions, regimental weapons company (81mm mortars, 65mm infantry guns). Non-motorized divisions dependent on horse-drawn transport.

sources.title: Biography of Major-General Pietro Maggiani
sources.author: Generals.dk
sources.details: Pietro Maggiani born February 1, 1887. Promoted to Brigadier-General July 1, 1937. Advanced to Major-General May 31, 1940 (with seniority from January 1, 1940). Commanded 55th Infantry Division 'Savona' from September 1, 1939 through November 3, 1941. Later commanded 6th Division 'Cuneo' December 15, 1942 to January 16, 1943. Became POW in Germany September 21, 1943 through May 1945.

sources.details: Compared Savona (non-motorized binary) with AS-type autotrasportabile divisions (Bologna, Brescia, Pavia) to confirm organizational differences. Savona had significantly less motorization (~165 vehicles vs 500+ for AS-type), larger horse-drawn wagon complement (680 vs 0), and lower operational radius (50km vs 120km+).

historical_context.deployment_history: Division deployed to Libya before Italy entered the war (June 10, 1940). Stationed in Libya throughout 1940 in garrison/reserve role. Division present during British Operation Compass (December 9, 1940 - February 7, 1941) but exact role uncertain. Lost artillery regiment (12° SILA) during British winter offensive 1940-41.
historical_context.operational_status_1940q4: Reserve/garrison operations in Tripolitania region. Division at full strength Q4 1940 before British Operation Compass losses. Combat readiness good (75%) but untested in major combat operations.
historical_context.future_fate: Division lost artillery regiment during Operation Compass winter 1940-41. Ultimately destroyed at Bardia in November 1941 during British Operation Crusader. Officially declared lost January 17, 1942.
historical_context.notes: Binary (binaria) division with 2 infantry regiments rather than traditional 3-regiment organization. Non-motorized division distinguished from AS-type autotrasportabile divisions (Bologna, Brescia, Pavia, Catanzaro) by heavy reliance on horse-drawn transport. Division recruited from southern Italy (Salerno and Cosenza home stations). Q4 1940 represents division at full strength on eve of British Operation Compass offensive that would inflict severe losses on Italian forces in Libya and Egypt.
